name: SecretsManagerCreateOrUpdateSecret
description: Updates a secret, optionally creating a secret if it does not exist
author: Amazon Web Services
helpMarkDown:
Please refer to [Secrets Manager](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/secretsmanager/latest/userguide/) for more information.

More information on this task can be found in the [task reference](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vsts/latest/userguide/secretsmanager-create-update.html).

####Task Permissions
This task requires permissions to call the following AWS service APIs (depending on selected task options, not all APIs may be used):
* secretsmanager:CreateSecret
* secretsmanager:PutSecretValue
* secretsmanager:UpdateSecret

inputs.name: awsCredentials
inputs.label: AWS Credentials
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specifies the AWS credentials to be used by the task in the build agent environment.

You can specify credentials using a service endpoint (of type _AWS_) in the task configuration or you can leave unspecified. If unspecified the task will attempt to obtain credentials from the following sources in order:

* From task variables named _AWS.AccessKeyID_, _AWS.SecretAccessKey_ and optionally _AWS.SessionToken_.
* From credentials set in environment variables in the build agent process. When using environment variables in the build agent process you may use the standard AWS environment variables: _AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID_, _AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY_ and optionally _AWS_SESSION_TOKEN_.
* If the build agent is running on an Amazon EC2 instance, from the instance metadata associated with the EC2 instance. For credentials to be available from EC2 instance metadata the instance must have been started with an instance profile referencing a role granting permissions to the task to make calls to AWS on your behalf. See [Using an IAM Role to Grant Permissions to Applications Running on Amazon EC2 Instances](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles_use_switch-role-ec2.html) for more information.

inputs.name: regionName
inputs.label: AWS Region
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The AWS region code (us-east-1, us-west-2 etc) of the region containing the AWS resource(s) the task will use or create. For more information see [AWS Regions and Endpoints](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html).

If a region is not explicitly configured the task will attempt to obtain the region to be used from the following sources:

* From a task variable named _AWS.Region_.
* From the standard AWS environment variable _AWS_REGION_ in the build agent's environment.
*  If the build agent is running on an Amazon EC2 instance, from instance metadata associated with the EC2 instance.

__Note:__ The regions listed in the picker are those known at the time this software was released. New regions that are not listed may still be used by entering the _region code_ of the region (for example _us_west_2_).

inputs.name: secretNameOrId
inputs.label: Secret Name
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specifies the friendly name of the new secret. The secret name must be ASCII letters, digits, or the following characters: /_+=.@- (spaces are not permitted).

Length Constraints: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 512.

If updating an existing secret you can specify either the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) or the friendly name of the secret.

inputs.name: secretValueSource
inputs.label: Secret Value Location
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies the source of the value to be stored in the secret. You can enter text values for secrets inline in the task configuration or in a file loaded when the task runs. Binary secret values must be loaded from a file.

inputs.name: secretValue
inputs.label: Secret Value
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specifies the text value that you want to store in this secret. For storing multiple values, we recommend that you use a JSON text string argument and specify key/value pairs.

Required if _Secret Value Location_ is set to _Inline_.

inputs.name: secretValueType
inputs.label: Secret Value Type
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specifies whether the file contents being stored in the secret text or binary data.

*Note:* to satisfy the service's API requirements the task will automatically base-64 encode secrets specified as binary type; you do not need to perform the base-64 encoding prior to specifying the secret value in the task.

inputs.name: secretValueFile
inputs.label: Path to File Containing Secret Value
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specifies the file containing the value (text or binary) that you want to store in this secret.

Required if _Secret Value Location_ is set to _From File_.

inputs.name: kmsKeyId
inputs.label: KMS Key ID
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Speciﬁes the ARN or alias of the AWS KMS customer master key (CMK) to be used to encrypt the secret.

If you don't specify this value, then Secrets Manager defaults to using the AWS account's default CMK (the one named aws/secretsmanager). If a KMS CMK with that name doesn't yet exist, then Secrets Manager creates it for you automatically the ﬁrst time it needs to encrypt a secret.

*Important* You can use the account's default CMK to encrypt and decrypt only if you call this operation using credentials from the same account that owns the secret. If the secret is in a diﬀerent account, then you must create a custom CMK and specify the ARN in this ﬁeld.

inputs.name: autoCreateSecret
inputs.label: Create secret if it does not exist
inputs.helpMarkDown: If the specified secret does not exist, attempt to create a new secret. Secrets Manager automatically attaches the staging label _AWSCURRENT_ to the new version. If this option is not selected, the task will return an error if the secret cannot be found.

inputs.name: tags
inputs.label: Tags for New Secret
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional list of tags (key-value pairs) that can be assigned to the new secret. Enter as Key=Value, one per line. Up to 50 tags can be applied to a secret.

inputs.name: arnOutputVariable
inputs.label: Output variable name to contain the secret's ARN
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional name of a variable to store the ARN of the new or updated secret on task completion.

inputs.name: versionIdOutputVariable
inputs.label: Output variable name to contain the secret's version ID
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional name of a variable to store the version ID of the new or updated secret on task completion.

inputs.name: logRequest
inputs.label: Log Request
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, request headers and other data for calls to AWS services are logged to the task's debug log.

inputs.name: logResponse
inputs.label: Log Response
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, the response metadata and body content of non-streaming responses from calls to AWS services are output to the task's debug log. The unique request ID, which can be useful when contacting AWS for support, is always logged to the task output regardless of this option setting.

messages.SecretNotFound: Specified secret does not exist, cannot proceed with update.
messages.SecretNotFoundAutoCreating: Specified secret does not exist. 'Create secret if it does not exist' was set true for task - attempting to create a new secret.
messages.SecretCreated: Successfully created new secret named %s, ARN '%s'.
messages.SettingVersionIdOutputVariable: Setting version ID for secret into task output variable %s
messages.SettingArnOutputVariable: Setting ARN for new secret into task output variable %s
messages.TooManyTags: %s tags were specified for the task. The service permits a maximum of %s.
